Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation2: My dog becomes vocal in the hallway when people pass near shared doors.
Story: I woke up early, the excitement of our family’s holiday celebration buzzing in the air. My mom had already texted, reminding me to help set up the decorations and bring my famous cookies. As a sister, I knew how much these traditions meant to everyone, especially my younger brother, who looked forward to our silly games and stories every year. But as I was getting ready, I heard my dog barking loudly in the hallway. I peeked out and saw Mrs. Lee, my neighbor, wincing as she hurried past our door. She’d mentioned before how the noise startled her and her toddler. I felt a knot tighten in my stomach. I wanted to be the reliable sister, present and cheerful for my family, but I also didn’t want to be the neighbor who ignored the needs of those living around me. The pressure from both sides pressed in—my family waiting for me, my neighbor hoping for peace. I stood in the hallway, torn, my dog’s barks echoing the conflict inside me.
